The SP 500 does not have a set reconstitution schedule changes to the index are made on an ongoing, asneeded basis. Additions and deletions are announced at 515 p.m. ET and typically become effective no less than three business days after the implementation Effective Date. 13 These announcements are available to the public via before, or at the same time, they are available to clients or the affected companies. Any company that is removed from the SP 500 may not be considered as a replacement candidate for the index until at least one year after its index removal date. What Happened to Index Effect? A ThreeDecade Look at SP 500 Adds and Drops spglobal.com

Wrong. Only people who dont do their due diligence dont know what the company does at this point. PLTR was wrapped in controversy a few years ago when their Gotham product proved a little too effective at predictive policing. Police would basically be targeting certain hoods based on past crime data. Now their latest product, AIP, basically creates a digital twin of your assets, and takes all source intelligence into account to create efficient uses of those assets, i.e. troop movements, oil drilling, and other use cases. Cisco uses PLTR and has reported huge efficiency gains, and a bunch of other big companies use AIP as well. To say no one knows what they do just shows your ignorance and lack of due diligence. Edit Im also up 300 on some of my PLTR shares, so your little downvotes just make me smile _

They are secretive about what their software does but it doesnt mean no one knows what they do. As a data scientist thats been following PLTR for 5 years, I feel like I have a good grasp so here it is in as few words as possible They are data consultants that have proprietary productivity tools that are allegedly better than the rest. Their tools are highly opinionated, as in they force you to setup your data in a way that is amenable to the way their software analyzes data. Highly opinionated means less flexibility, and this is the complete opposite of what the industry is doing, which is to maximize flexibility by offering every niche solution as a SaaS product and hiring a bunch of data engineers to do the custom integration. Bull case is that their productivity tools are not only top tier but also scalable, as in they can become more of a monolithic SaaS company and less of a consulting company over the next few years. Also, if anyone figures out how to manage autonomous agents that can execute business logic within organizations, its going to be MSFT or PLTR. Sorry AMZN, GOOG, and CRM. Bear case is that their productivity tools are just mid and the secret sauce is their forward deployed engineers that get paid enormous salaries at the expense of stock holders, which would make them an overpriced consulting company.

Lets say you collect Pokemon cards. You have a 10,000 cards at each of your 10 different neighbors houses, so 100,000 different cards. You need to build the best deck possible to win the next tournament. Your friend Pete offers to go through all your cards and optimize the best deck possible. He also makes sure none are stolen, helps you control which of your buddies has access to which cards and makes sure they are returned. He also sleeves all the cards and makes puts them neatly in binders. The day before the tournament, 13 of your deck is banned. Pete in 30 minutes, again goes through all your cards and builds the best deck again.

The deadline for 10K was missed and they are late. Now they have to file a 12b25 form with the SEC, and they said they would do it by the end of today. If they file it, they will automatically be granted a 15 day extension for 10K, and if the filing is made within the extension period, it will be deemed by SEC as to have been filed on time and no further action is taken by the SEC. Itll be very interesting if they miss it again, and even if they dont, what reason for delay will they provide this time, since its not their first time theyre filing a 12b25, and what else will be shown in the form. Regardless, the timing of getting crisis management veteran on board and book cooking allegations dont bode well. This is something one could expect from a SPAC, not a SP listed company.

Largescale liquid cooling is a meme and theres no innovative valueadd to it. Its not rocket science, you run pipes from blocks that get hot to radiators somewhere else and pump water through them in a loop. We cracked this technology in the 1800s, we were putting it in cars when radio waves were just a theory. The reason its never been widely deployed in datacentres is that it doesnt make sense economically. Hotcold aisle containment is massively cheaper and good enough for the overwhelming majority of use cases, and even when its not, its basically always cheaper to just build more square footage of datacenter and pack your hot servers together less dense.

But I have _a lot_ of friends whore datacenter engineers at large tech companies and none of them think this is the future, and its not because they havent looked into it. Its increasingly an inconvenient necessity for some GPU compute, but even then its a shakey costbenefit trade off. Friend, I dunno how old you are or what youve done in life, but I dont need to listen Jim Cramer and his balloonhead costars to learn about this stuff. I work in tech and I have friends who are respected industry professionals specialising in this exact specific topic. Theyre happy to explain in detail why it doesnt work, if only to rant off their frustrations about all the stupid conversations they keep having to have about it with upper management. This is how tech hype cycles work, its always like this.
Lol

But I have a lot of friends whore datacenter engineers at large tech companies and none of them think this is the future, and its not because they havent looked into it. Perhaps they should talk to Jensen. Who may know a thing or two about that. The next one soon coming is liquid cooled. Its beautiful in lots of ways. Its just not him. Others are saying the same. We know people will eventually have to move to liquid, but we also hear feedback from customers that thats challenging. For them, their data centers arent there, they need to build new data centers. Earlier this month, Dells CEO revealed in an earnings call that the upcoming Nvidia B100 GPU would have a thermal design point TDP of 1kW up from 700W in the H100. That would not necessitate direct liquid cooling, he said, but it would definitely be needed next year with the B200.
Yes lol

Its quite obvious you havent been around that long... You believe whatever you need to... Id also suggest talking to a lot of people over 60. They were promised a lot of these delusions of grandeur as well. Most of them are in their 60s and 70s still punching time clocks for 40 hours a week. 70 percent of everyone is also still dying in debt. They could use some of those robots youll never see in your lifetime. I was promised flying cars....

I am 34 rn , not as old as you. I dont believe in granduer or anything but this from my personal exerience I didnt have a mobile phone till I was 15 or 16. I didnt have have internet , in fact computers were rare when I was in school. People said there wil be a time when everyone will have their own computer. It is funny right, that is what I listened to when I first operated a pc. We used floppy discs in school. The world has come a lot way since with Internet of things taking over. I dont need to think we will have massive AI during my lifetime, but it can happen after I am dead. The world has changed a lot since then , and it keeps changing. Tech keeps evolving. We do have flying cars but they are not feasible. I often think science fiction has roots in the real world and a lot of science fiction did come through in my lifetime. Back in my country, we used to stand in lines waiting at an international calling booth to make an international call, the charges were per second. Today , we have a screen , and we can see other people no matter where they live. The world has changed so much. Internet of things , touch screens of all devices and PCs everywhere, holograms, everything was the stuff of fiction.

As an American, let me tell you something... We had all that stuff you spoke of in the late 80s and early 90s. Your reality does not define actual reality... The bottom line is... Unless it gives someone important more control over population.it probably isnt happening...
Let me be more specific... Affordable flying cars... Not some modern twist on a plane or helicopter...
Do you think we will never achieve technological progress
Weve been progressing... Just not as fast as everyone likes to pretend were.

Just remember theres three rules to this game. 1 It has to make money. 2 If it makes money and never breaks or. improves... It doesnt make money. 3 It has to make money forever! Thats how the economic system of slavery works...

We used to progress faster than this in the early 1900s than we do right now btw. We have been quite slow compared to the past in the recent decades. A lot of tech today is also based on some innovations and theories like from a hundred years or so ago.
Which means... You need to make money to spend it.

This is an opinion not a fact. Innovation just happens when needed , I think. We have a new war, we innovate , we need to blow up people in a better way , we innovate. Thats just what I believe. Innovation happens when we need it , and profit is also one of those needs. We cured people from diseases because it was a need , not exactly profit. And we waste money in wars because it is needed. I live in the States btw , was not born here.
Thats because nothings really new... Its just reused and modernized...
For instance the first known GPS guided anything was a missile in 1938... Theyre now trying to use that same technology in self driving cars. So new and innovative...
No, innovation happens at the government level, and they just sell it to us when theyve got something new to play with.

All Im saying is just dont be shocked when tech hits a standstill for a decade or two. Thats pretty much how I felt until recently. Social media isnt new either... I talked to people on AOL in the late 80s. The cloud is nothing more than mass data collection centers. Which tells whomever whatever they need to know about you while simultaneously speeding everything up because the centers are closer to you. Back in the day, the closest data center couldve been several states away.

Northern Europe wellfare country here. Our supposedly free Healthcare etc. Costs 4060 income tax, the bulk of which is wasted on salaries for the bureaucrats administering those taxes. Free for all also means its crap. Our hospitals and the treatments offered, looks like something from the middle ages. Public transportation is garbage cars here cost a million millions becauseof extra taxes, but living without one is more depressing than AIDS, which, btw, You cant avoid getting if you spend time in public transportation, free indoctrination schools or medieval hospitals.

Healthcare is about 100 euro per year. I spend 80 euro a month on gaswaterelectric and 80 on telecom, 800 rent. Car insurance is 100 euro per month fuel is like 3 times as expensive as the US, other insurances probably another 50. There is a busline from my front door to my work but I hate public transport so I take my car. Havent used my bike in a decade even though Im actually Dutch. Fuck bikes, if god existed and wanted me to bike he wouldnt have let people invent internal combustion engines. If you go unemployed you keep receiving 70 of your income for like half a year before they start to decrease the payments. Also roughly 35 PTO days, near unlimited sick leave. Oh my contract automatically tracks inflation. Some funsies Income tax does go up to 52 here though, so my employer pays out part of my salary in mealcheques which is subtracted from your gross before the taxman comes. So my groceries are untaxed except for VAT. Same with ecocheques which you can spend on green things, and Consumption cheques which you can spend on just about anything. Its some weird government facilitated tax evasion scheme. More funnies No capital gains tax in Belgium as long as you dont do daytrading or speculativehigh risk trading. If you LARP as a boomer trader the taxman doesnt care. Also if you buy Belgium or Ireland domiciled stonks you also dont pay the 1,32 tax for purchase of stonks. Dividends are taxed at 30 if you go above 800 a year. So the free money glitch here is to just put any money you dont need as a buffer into IWDA which is Ireland domiciled, reinvests the dividends into the fund, and it is roughly 60 SP500. Its not really so simple as rates go down, markets go up, and you have to see the larger market context. In a strong growth environment, rate cuts might typically give a stock market boost, but in a weakening soft landing economy, they can do the opposite, a brief spike up and reversal notwithstanding. Additional rate cuts can precede even more market drop, but there truly isnt a direct universal correlation, because its about larger context. Look at 2007, which is a similar analog to today in some ways prior to rate cuts in Sept, the market dropped 23 weeks and we may see that again here, then markets surged on the cut announcement, went up to new all time highs which we may also see again here as of SeptOct, like SP to 5800? 5900?. After the all time high peak, stocks then started their 18 month drop, even as rates kept dropping in salvage mode. Here now, the SP could easily touch 3900 into next year before a strong rebound, based on chart setups. No guarantees of course, but hence why I think its best to wait and watch a bit, risk is legitimately high going forward here. Watch the bond rates too, which are a leading indicator to the Fed funds rate or watch TLT going upward ahead as an inverse, it is set up to continue a new up trend. Fed rate changes always lag, but the bond rates dropping are also cluing in a weak economy ahead, not strong. Rate cuts in this environment actually reduce govt interest expenditure which is a massive source of liquidity that gets funneled into markets, essentially draining liquidity that the markets need to keep going up, and spurredon private borrowing on lower rates if it even happens isnt going to overpower that in a weakening environment. Similar to 2007 as well, and 2000, the technical chart pattern itself in each major index, SPX, NQ, RTY is now one of completing a multiyear run pattern, and at a large degree scale, not midrun or starting a new run. I think a lot of people feel like its 201617 about to repeat, rather than 2000 or 200708. But this is a different market context now than the last 1012 years, much more akin to 2007 in pattern, or more so 2000 in context and aftermath or even 1929, but I doubt we see any straight plunge like 29, more like a grind down and up with multiple plunges. There are no crystal balls obviously, just correlated clues and patterns, but together it hints at a rough riskreward skew going forward, and a rough frustrating and quite volatile buyandhold environment for the next decade, like holding through the 1970s or 2000s, maybe worse, though there would surely be some very strong swings upward.

Part of the 1.4 is a bond ladder for the first 5 years so that youre not withdrawing anything from your port for at least the first 5 years. This protects you from the potential of a terrible downswing in the market. The biggest way you can get into to trouble with your retirement money is to be withdrawing a large amount each year while the market is tanking. Its the worstcase scenario. To avoid this, you have a bond ladder that covers you for the first 5. Sure, youll have the vast majority of the money in VOO or VTSAX and then assuming returns are decent, youll be golden. In my case, the 1.4 has to do with the HCOL area that I live in. Im in a city in California where an extremely mediocre 32 1500 sq. ft. home goes for like 900k.

I figured you were new, thats okay. Try to learn as much as you can about options before you waste your cash. There is a metric to options, several actually, but one in particular called implied volatility IV for short. Iv plays a factor into options price, and iv is driven by expected events that would drive market price. Earnings is a big one, dates of known contract announcements or company announcements. The market knows all of this and tracks it through IV. The closer you get to these events, the IV will rise, causing the price of an option to rise with it. So by buying options for known events as far away from them as you can stomach, the cheaper you can get that same option for. You have to balance that with how much you think the price will change before that event though. Options are simple yet complicated. So if you buy an option today for earnings tomorrow, it will likely be as expensive as that option gets. Starting the moment the event happens, the iv begins to drop dramatically, lowering the price of the option. This is known as iv crush if you have heard that term used.

Buy post puts or gtfo. I read 1 paragraph of the DD before giving up. But GPT read and responded in 5seconds The critique youve provided rests on a few misconceptions and overlooks key aspects of AIs current trajectory and potential. 1. AI Approaches and Progress The critique dismisses the GPTML approach as a known dead end, but this perspective fails to account for the significant advancements these methods have already achieved. While its true that current AI systems are not equivalent to human intelligence or capable of fulfilling science fictionlike fantasies e.g., J.A.R.V.I.S., this was never their immediate goal. The successes of GPT3, GPT4, and similar models in natural language processing, image generation, and other domains are impressive and provide immense value across industries. 2. Exponential Investment for Linear Gains The notion of exponential investment for linear gains is not unique to AI. Most technological progress, particularly in nascent fields, requires substantial investment before significant breakthroughs are realized. The idea that AI is stagnating is contradicted by ongoing improvements in model capabilities, optimization techniques, and the emergence of new architectures that continue to push the boundaries of whats possible. 3. Business Case for AI The critique argues that AI has failed to meet investor expectations by not delivering a fully autonomous system capable of complex tasks like designing cars. However, this expectation misunderstands the nature of AI development. AI is not meant to be an allencompassing solution to every problem overnight. Incremental improvements, such as automating specific tasks, enhancing decisionmaking, and creating new products, are already transforming industries. The ultimate goals may be ambitious, but the journey itself is valuable and profitable. 4. Training Data and Resources Concerns about running out of training data or resources ignore the adaptability of AI research. Techniques like transfer learning, unsupervised learning, and more efficient model architectures help mitigate these challenges. Moreover, the development of specialized hardware, improved algorithms, and better data utilization strategies continuously address the resourceintensive nature of AI. 5. Nvidias Role While its true that tech giants are moving towards vertical integration, Nvidia remains a critical player in the AI hardware ecosystem. The dominance of CUDA, the ongoing innovation in GPU architecture, and the importance of a robust softwarehardware ecosystem are not easily replaced or replicated. Nvidias role may evolve, but it is far from obsolete. 6. Investor Expectations The critique implies that investors are disillusioned, yet the continued flow of capital into AI suggests otherwise. While there may be some adjustments as the field matures, the broader trajectory of AI investment remains strong, driven by both immediate applications and longterm potential. In summary, while AIs development is complex and requires tempered expectations, dismissing the entire field as a bubble fails to appreciate the genuine advancements and ongoing potential that AI, particularly machine learning, continues to unlock.

Because they are investing in the next wave of labor replacements for the said trillions of future revenue? It turns out you need to invest now to see revenue later. You are also wrong about improvement costs being completely exponential. That is true for the scaling wide increasing parameter count and training time, but scaling vertically is much more efficient. I use the latest models every day for programming and it seems like every week theres something new that can solve some problems the previous model couldnt solve. The current state of the art is focused on improving training and making a corpus of training data have better results. The gains are spectacular. Microsofts Phi 3.5 mini came out last week and has 3.8B parameters. It outperforms Llama 2 70B from a year ago on benchmarks. Thats almost 20x less parameters and possibly training time. They did this by improving training methodology and making training data higher quality. So methodology is leading to huge improvements. Hyper scale companies are continuing to scale wide AND implement these methodologies. This means each generation is getting better and better and we have a while before we get to scraping the bottom of the barrel of the gains.

The Jarvis is ridiculous only sounds silly if youve started paying attention to this in the last year or two. You can look up what folks like Sam Altman were saying 5 years ago. Here he is in 2019 openly saying they have no real path to profitability and once we make AI good enough itll just tell us how to make a return. A year ago the entire field was bristling with excitement about AGI and superintelligence, its a relatively recent development that theyve walked expectations back. Theyre just doing the fusion power is 5 years away thing. Heres Sam himself talking down GPT4 2 months before it came out and a couple months ago saying its mildly embarrassing at best and heres him saying largely the same thing nearly 6 years ago The current thing is always good enough for some tasks and the true AGI future is just a few years away. The issue isnt that it takes time, the issue is in 2020 when they released GPT3 theyd raised less than 100m, and today theyve raised over 13B, and they dont have a lot to show for that extra 12.9B. Sams talking about burning 50 billion a year to build AGI and its just got people wondering how many rounds well have to go on this before we get whats actually promised. At the end of the day its not his 50 billion to burn, his company isnt profitable so its gotta come from other people who arent going to keep ponying up if theres no progress to show for it. Obviously the AI sector is bigger than OpenAI, but theyre the best example. True AGI would be worth near infinite investment, but 400B for the current state of AI wasnt worth it, the longer this goes the more investors will just see it as throwing good money after bad.

Longer dated contracts perform best when deep in the money. Its simple. Each option consist of a strike price and the right to 100 shares. In this case, OP bought 1 put option on Jul betting that Dell stocks will go below 121 per share by August 9th. Then on August 9th, OP sold the option. Since Dell stock is well below the 121 strike price, he makes a lot of money here. However, if it did not go below 121, the option expires worthless.

No thats an EMP. Its Electronic Funds Transfer. To ME, those are a good place to put your funds.

OP bought the option from someone else who sold the option. So he didnt need to own any shares in this scenario. Once he owns the option, he can sell the option or exercise it to own 100 shares. Since he doesnt have the capital in this case to exercise it, its better to just sell the option to make profit. Some people can sell options without owning the shares as well, but usually brokerage requires X amount of money in their account. Usually 25k depending on whichever brokerage company. This scenario is called naked since they dont have the stocks originally. If they do that and the strike price crosses the target, they will owe 100 x the price of the stock at the exercise time.

I wrote about this extensively in a prior post. I was at Bell LabsLucent just prior to the implosion. Companies like Dell and Intel have that stale hardware company smell that Lucent did just prior to them tanking. Old companies, serving old markets with old employees. Time to retire them. A couple of observations from someone with 30 years experience in systems engineering One, ATT and Lucent buildings were full of nonproducers, particularly at the PMdirectorexecutive level. I remember one director in particular that had multiple CRTs in his office that showed the tickers for all our vendors stock he had been giftedgrifted. Only time he ever interacted with me was to yell at me when he heard I got offered a bunch of preIPO stock from a vendor and I declined given I felt it was a conflict of Interest. Two, some hardware projects cannot be remote because they need lab workspace. Hardware companies that devote 100 of their real estate to hardware labs and outsource everything else will be more successful than compeditors that dont. Putting employees that dont need to be there offcampus improves the bottom line. Three, Linux is the most successful software engineering and operating system project in human history and has been 100 remote since its inception. It also buriedbankrupted all its commercial Unix competitors. So put that in your pipe and smoke it, regards. Edit If you regards knew what OpenAI actually did your heads would collectively explode.

My understanding is that whatever irregularities occurred in the SCMI accounting happened last spring, and that the person responsible was fired back then.

We dont yet know the nature or extent if those irregularities, but whatever they were caused enough blowback that the auditors resigned the account.

It seems to me that given the company acted upon the problem when it was discovered, that action strongly suggests that there was no company-wide intent to defraud, and that the SEC is likely to levy a fine, probably place the company on an extended probation, increase scrutiny on the companys future financial reporting, etc.

Here is a rundown of policy differences. This is not an endorsement.Mr. Trump recently stated that he supports reducing the top corporate income tax bracketfrom 21% to 15% in order to help companies like DELL to compete strongly against foreigncompetitors. 7 years ago, Mr. Trump spearheaded reducing the rate from 35% to 21%.Ms. Harris proposes increasing the top corporate rate from 21% to 28%, a 25% increase inincome tax DELL would have to pay instead of investing in it's growth.Mr. Trump wants to maintain the current long-term capital gains tax on sales of DELL stockat 15% and 20% for higher earners.Ms. Harris proposes taxing capital gains taxes as ordinary earnings. So an investor in the 28% marginal income tax bracket would see in increase in capital gains taxes on DELL stock sales from 15% to 28%, almost doubling the tax owed. Ms. Harris also proposes, with Mr. Biden,to impose the tax on "unrealized" gains, on DELL stock that an investor owns but has not yetsold. The unrealized gain tax would be imposed on higher earners.Mr. Trump lowered personal income tax brackets across the board in 2017. Those reductions will "sunset" (end) in 2025 if they are not renewed. Mr. Trump wants to renew them. Ms. Harris avoids the subject, but Mr. Biden has expressed disdain for the 2017 reductions. The increased standard deduction would also sunset. If the brackets sunset and increase to the pre-2017 levels, so too would the cap-gains tax with Harris's proposal.

According to Birinyi Associates, DELL has a forward P/E of 12.95 as of 09/07/24. The S&P 500 index has a forward P/E of 23.58 according to "The Wall Street Journal". So, if you can believe analysts' estimates, DELL stock is roughly half as expensive as the S&P 500 index on a forward P/E basis. I expect DELL's earnings per share to grow faster than the S&P 500 aggregate EPS, so that tells me that DELL stock is likely to outperform the S&P 500 index over the coming days, weeks and months.  But, even if DELL's EPS only grow at the same rate as the S&P 500's aggregate EPS, DELL stock will probably still outperform the S&P 500 index, because of its much lower valuation.  DELL still trades at a steep discount to the S&P 500, even though it's a tech stock exposed to the fast-growing AI segment.
